Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Logical Localization for Mobile Devices through Ambience Sensing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The notion of location is broad, ranging from physical coordinates (latitude/longitude) to logical locations (like Starbucks, WalMart, museums). Logical locations are gaining importance because they express the context of the user, allowing applications to carry out context-specific interaction. For instance, a person entering Starbucks may receive an advertisement for purchasing coffee. Evidently, such applications expect to learn the existence of the user within the confines of a logical place (like Starbucks). The rich body of localization literature based on GPS/WiFi/GSM is dominantly physical in nature, and translating them to logical locations is error prone. This is because a dividing wall may separate two logical locations and an error margin of few meters may place the mobile device on the incorrect side of this wall.

This proposal proposes a unique system called SurroundSense that breaks away from physical localization and investigates direct methods of recognizing logical locations. The main idea in SurroundSense exploits the observation that a logical place has a distinct ambience in terms of its background sound, light, color, RF signals, and layout. The attributes of the ambience can be sensed through mobile phone sensors and suitably combined to form a fingerprint of that place. This fingerprint can then be used to identify the logical location of the phone by comparing it against an existing database of location-fingerprints. As an example, a Starbucks may include sound signatures from coffee machines and microwaves that are different from the clinking of forks and spoons in restaurants. Similarly, signature colors in the decor may vary from store to store, lighting styles and store layouts may be different, and so will the WiFi SSIDs audible at that location. The combination of all these attributes, a fingerprint, is likely to exhibit reasonable diversity for high quality, logical localization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative, multi-university project has focused on sensing context of mobile applications and their usage characteristics. A mobile application’s context can be defined in many different ways. It could be the location of use, time of use, the networks through which they connect, and the performance their experience. All of these factors impact the user’s experience of the mobile application. 

To understand this context of mobile applications, we have developed a software component that any mobile application developer can install within their application. This library allows the system to anonymously track the ambient information and provides useful information that the developer can use to improve the overall user experience.

In this project we have worked extensively with one mobile game developer and have used the developed library to instrument their application. Towards the end of this project, the mobile application had collected more than 1,000,000 users. The specific application is a massively multi-player online role playing game and has its users distributed over more than 100 countries. Through this instrumentation library, we have been able to analyze the behavior of various cellular networks worldwide, and their relative performances, across all these locations. For instance, through this software library and its users, we are able to provide a sample of performance of various ISPs globally from a neutral viewpoint.


Finally, we have ourselves released a specialized network performance monitoring app in the iOS and Android app stores (called NetworkTest). Users can download this app and can learn their own network’s performance at their current and potentially future locations. A view of this NetworkTest app is also provided in this report. The figure with the app’s screenshot shows that a user currently in Wisconsin, USA is experiencing a network path delay of 181.81 milliseconds on average. The app can compare this experience to the average experienced by all users in the entire state of Wisconsin or of the entire country. It can also provide users a large number of other ways of understanding this performance in their local context.
